title: 110_hr360
content:
The Act is titled "The 9-11 Commission Combating Proliferation Implementation Act" and includes the establishment of the Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction. The Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction is established within the Executive Office of the President. The head of the Office is the Director, with a Deputy Director assisting in carrying out responsibilities and serving as Acting Director when needed. Both positions are appointed by the President with Senate approval and serve at the President's pleasure. No person can hold the Director or Deputy Director position while serving in another federal government role. The Director of the Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction is responsible for developing policies, goals, and strategies to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in the United States. They serve as the principal advisor to the President on these matters and coordinate the implementation of the prevention strategy by federal agencies. The Director of the Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction is responsible for developing policies, goals, and strategies to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in the United States. They oversee the execution of the Strategy by federal agencies, direct the development of annual budgets, certify budget consistency, and carry out other related responsibilities as deemed necessary by the President. The Director has the authority to develop annual budgets for preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, provide guidance, coordinate budgets with agency heads, and approve budgets for each element of prevention. The Director has the authority to transfer funds between accounts and agencies for the prevention of weapons of mass destruction, appoint necessary personnel, and develop annual budgets for this purpose. The Director can request personnel from different departments for implementing the Strategy, use services of Federal agencies on a reimbursable basis, and hire experts and consultants as needed. The Director can request personnel from different departments, use services of Federal agencies on a reimbursable basis, and hire experts and consultants as needed. The Director shall evaluate the performance of any employee detailed to the Office for purposes of the applicable performance appraisal system. The Director may provide periodic bonus payments to employees detailed to the Office, not exceeding 20% of basic pay. The total compensation, including bonuses, awards, and basic pay, should not exceed the annual rate for level III positions. The maximum number of personnel that can be detailed to another department or agency is specified. The Director may provide bonus payments to employees detailed to the Office, not exceeding 20% of basic pay. The maximum number of personnel that can be detailed to another department or agency is specified. Details under subsection (d)(4) expire at the end of the fiscal year unless extended by law. The Director must submit the Strategy developed under subsection (c)(3) to Congress by June 1, 2008, with any legislative change recommendations. Annual reports are required after 2007. The Director must submit an updated Strategy and recommendations to Congress annually. They are responsible for developing a Global Coalition with foreign governments to prevent weapons of mass destruction proliferation. The Office's location in the Executive Office of the President does not limit Congress's access. The Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction allows Congress access to information, documents, and personnel. Amendments are made to the pay structure for the Director and Deputy Director of the Office. Authorization of appropriations for the Office for Combating the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction. SEC. 102. The President should request the Russian President to designate an official for preventing weapons of mass destruction. The official should have similar authorities to the Director and coordinate activities in Russia. The term "prevention of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction" includes activities under specified programs in various acts and authorizations. The term "weapons of mass destruction" includes chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons, as well as materials used in their manufacture. It encompasses activities authorized under specific programs related to the prevention of the proliferation of such weapons. TITLE II--GLOBAL CLEANOUT

Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of Energy to carry out a program under the Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005, with $100,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year. 

TITLE III--EXPANSION OF PROLIFERATION SECURITY INITIATIVE

Sense of Congress regarding the expansion of the Proliferation Security Initiative. The Sense of Congress is to expand and strengthen the Proliferation Security Initiative, including countries outside of NATO. The United States should work with the United Nations to develop a Security Council Resolution authorizing the initiative under international law. Authorization of $50,000,000 for joint training exercises on weapons of mass destruction interdiction under the Proliferation Security Initiative for fiscal year 2008. Emphasis on inviting non-participating countries to observe exercises and training with new Initiative members. Authorization of appropriations for Cooperative Threat Reduction Programs. Authorization of appropriations for Cooperative Threat Reduction programs totaling $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $550,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $600,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $650,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $700,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Additionally, there is a provision for permanent waiver authority for a chemical weapons destruction facility in Russia. Section 1305 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 shall not apply to funds for a chemical weapons destruction facility in Russia if the President certifies it is in the national security interest and includes a plan for disclosure by Russia. This includes a removal of funding limitation on activities outside the former Soviet Union. Section 1308(c) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 is repealed. The President must submit a report to Congress every 6 months starting April 1, 2008, addressing liability concerns and impediments to renegotiating Cooperative Threat Reduction programs. The term "Cooperative Threat Reduction programs" refers to specified programs in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1997.
